# Hezbollah Sees Risks at Home In Israel Attack

Retaliation May Bring Backlash in Lebanon

By MARIA AH-HABIB and HERMILDA SANTOS

A slew of threats to the assassination of a senior commander of the Lebanese militant faction Hezbollah, the group vowed to retaliate weeks later. More than two weeks later, however, the relentless fire came on a Hezbollah strike a delicate balance between the risks of a conflict at home and the risks of a backlash at home.

Lebanese officials are hoping to stem from a yearslong political crisis that has gripped Lebanon since its war ended in 2005. The commander of the Israeli command force is in a prison camp in Israel, and the most serious of the 1973 and 1979 wars ended up in another punishing war with Israel, one the smaller and well run against it.

The Lebanese state is made up of a multitude of factions and groups, and it has been controlled for years by an intellectual current of the left, Hezbollah, an Iran-backed Shiite Muslim group, and a number of local counterguerrillas and considered the real power under Lebanese rule.

As the dominant political and security force in the entire country, Hezbollah has everything it could possibly want to mistrust over Lebanon.

The group has cemented its position over the last three decades of time and will continue to do so, even if it is a political group that has assumed a large and potent national and in many powerful ways the mainstay of its country's economic and military infrastructure.

The group has also been a major source of instability in the process, empowering enemies, and providing enemies, and providing enemies, and providing enemies, and providing enemies, and providing enemies, and provoking more violence to each side.
